apu (“chief”) → apuchay (“to honor”)

old (referring to a woman or female)

Used to indicate a progressive or ongoing action.
rimani (“I speak”) → rimachkani (“I am speaking”)
llamk'an (“he/she works”) → llamk'achkan (“he/she is working”)
suffix indicating that a speaker infers or conjectures something, as opposed to having direct knowledge of it, or having been told about it

Negative suffix. Used with mana to form negative statements, or ama to form negative commands.
Manam llamk'anchikchu.
We are not working.
Wak allquqa manam imanawarqanchu.
That dog did not do anything to me.
Ama mikhuychu!
Don't eat!

(transitive) to belt up, fasten with a belt
(transitive) to put a pot on a stove

Used to indicate a putative or conjectural statement.
Paqarinchá chayamunqa.
He/She might arrive tomorrow.
Imachá chay unquyqa?
What could that sickness be?
Mariya Qusquman rinqachá.
Maybe Maria will go to Cusco.

ima (“what”) → imahina (“how (lit. like what)”)

Inflectional suffix, limitative. Describes the goal or endpoint of an action; until.
Punukama chayan.
He/She arrives at Puno.
K'uychichawkama suyasunchik.
We will wait until Saturday.

to be
Maqtañam kani.I'm already an old person.
from this or from here, about this

knot (looping of a piece of string)

(transitive) to cut with a knife, not with scissors

Reflexive. To or for oneself.
mayllay (“to wash something”) → mayllakuy (“to wash oneself”)
rantiy (“to buy something”) → rantikuy (“to buy something for oneself”)

Used to form the plural of nouns, when the number or amount is not specified.
allqu (“dog”) → allqukuna (“dogs”)
a ritual to remove curses from a person
jacket shirt, dress shirt worn by men
guinea pig or rabbit, specifically male

the act of touching, caressing, or fondling

woven shoulder scarf or cape worn by women
(intransitive) to shine, glance, gleam, glow, flash, twinkle
billion, a milliard, a thousand million
(movement) to rise up, come out, (movement) to go out,

Evidential suffix, first-hand information. Indicates that the speaker has direct evidence/knowledge of some fact, having experienced it, seen it, heard it, etc.
Ñuqa runasimitam rimani. Qusqumantam kani.
I speak Quechua. I am from Cusco.
Allqukunaqa chawa aychatam mikhunku.
Dogs eat raw meat.

allative or dative case; indicates the direction of movement or the indirect object
Llaqtaman risaq.
I will go towards the town.
Paykunaman mikhunata apachkani.
I am taking food to them.

A suffix for the ablative case. Indicates origin of movement, topic of an utterance, or the makeup of something.
Qusqumantam kani.
I am from Cusco.
Runasimimanta rimachkani.
I am talking about Quechua.
Chicharutaqa khuchi aychamanta ruranku.
They make chicharrón from pork.
club (heavy stick used as a weapon)
(transitive) to embrace, carry in the arms
(transitive) to stretch, tauten, spread out, extend
the fruit of some kind of gourd
(transitive) to wrap, to bundle, to coil, to pack
(transitive) to request, demand, ask for, pray

Evidential suffix, first-hand information. Indicates that the speaker has direct evidence/knowledge of some fact, having experienced it, seen it, heard it, etc.
Paykunawanmi kachkani.
I am with them.
Kuchinillaqa chiwanway ukhuyuqmi.
The cochineal insect is deep red on the inside.
(transitive) to graze, pasture, shepherd, watch over a herd
food, meal, feeding trough, dish, bowl
(transitive) to entrust, ask a favor, assign a task, hire

cislocative, translocative.
apay (“to carry”) → apamuy (“to bring; to take”)
tiyay (“to sit”) → tiyamuy (“to come sit; to go sit”)

(transitive) to want, will
Tusuyta munani.I want to dance.
(intransitive) to appear in another person's dream

Indicates third-person singular possessive.
wasi (“house”) → wasin (“his/her/its house”)

Nominalizer, future perfect participle.
llamk'ay (“to work”) → llamk'ana (“tool, work to be done”)
mikhuy (“to eat”) → mikhuna (“food, meal”)

Indicates a reciprocal action.
maqay (“to beat”) → maqanakuy (“to fight one another”)
rikuy (“to see”) → rikunakuy (“to see each other”)

Desiderative.  To want to, to feel like.
mikhuy (“to eat”) → mikhunayay "to be hungry (lit. to want to eat)"

Indicates first-person inclusive plural possessive.
wasi (“house”) → wasinchik (“our (incl) house”)

First-person singular subject.
rimay (“to speak”) → ñuqa rimani (“I speak”)

Second-person singular subject.
rimay (“to speak”) → qam rimanki (“you speak”)

Second-person plural subject.
rimay (“to speak”) → qamkuna rimankichik (“you (pl) speak”)

Indicates third-person plural possessive.
wasi (“house”) → wasinku (“their house”)

Abessive, Privative. without
Ñuqa wasinnaqmi kani.
I am without a house.

Inclusive.  Like English together, with
Tawantinsuyu
"Four united provinces" (i.e. the Inca Empire)
Qamnintinmi kay wasipi yachani.
"I live in this house with you."

Genitive marker following vowels. See also: -pa
ñuqap sutiy
my name
(transitive) to get dressed, to put on clothes
(transitive) to cut, to divide something into two
porongo, gourd; container made from a pumpkin

Genitive marker following consonants. See also: -p
qampa sutiyki ("your name")
since, for a period of time
plant with red flowers used for making dye (Cosmos peucedanifolius)

A suffix for the dative or benefactive case; "for"
Qampaqmi kay wasi.
This house is for you.
to rain, Parachkanmi.It's raining right now.

also, too
Qamtapas khuyanim.
I love you as well.
Chay warmim tusuchkanpas takichkanpas.
That woman is dancing and singing.
Paypas ñuqapas risaqku.
He and I will go.
(transitive) to untie, detach, let loose, free

Repetitive. Many times, redundantly.
qhaway (“to look at”) → qhawapayay (“to observe”)
hamuy (“to come”) → hamupayay (“to visit repeatedly”)
gentian; a red-flowering plant of the puna
(onomatopoeia) the sound of a bird flapping its wings

A suffix for the locative case.
Wasipi saqirqani.
I left it at the house.
Huk watapiqa chunka iskayniyuq killam kan.
In one year there are twelve months.
Chaypim yachani.
I live there.
(transitive) to sweep, clean, erase, clear, wipe

Used to form subordinate clauses.
Paqarimuptinqa lliw pisqukunam waqayta qallarinku.
When dawn breaks, all the birds start singing.
Chirimuptin utaq paramuptinqa llikllawanmi qatakuni.
If it's cold or if it rains, I cover myself with a lliklla.
first spinning of yarn, resulting in irregular threads
(intransitive) to spout out (from a source or spring)
puma; cougar; mountain lion (Puma concolor, a large feline of the Americas)
lofty region, elevated cold plains, Andean altitude

Indicates certainty, determination, or firm intent
arí (“yes”) → arípuni (“absolutely”)
Qamwanpunim sawakuyta munani
I want to get married with you.

Suffix for the intrative case; "among, amidst"
Qharipuralla rimachkanku.
They are talking only among men.
(transitive) to lead, guide, bring (animals or people)

Agentive. Like English -er, -or
yachachiy (“to teach”) → yachachiq (“teacher”)
(intransitive) to smell, give off an odor
(transitive) to squeeze with the hands, knead, crush
(copula) to rest upon, lean on, be based on, (movement)
(transitive) to carry in a bundle or pack

Used to mark the topic of the sentence.
Llamataqa mikhuchichkanim.
I'm feeding the llama.
Karlusqa yachachiqmi.
Carlos is a teacher.

work done in the early morning, before breakfast

to throw water using the hands[1]
a mine, a place where ores are extracted from the earth

guinea pig or rabbit, often female
(transitive) to distribute, divide, share, pass out
(transitive) to lead, take by the hand
(transitive) to sell, (transitive) to buy for oneself

Continuity or permanence.  Like English still, yet.
mana (“no”) → manaraq "still no"
Aqha kanraqchu?
"Is there still chicha?"

Causative. Marks the cause or reason for something. Like English for, because.
ima (“what”) → imarayku (“why”)
Payraykum kaypi kachkani.
"I'm here because of him."

Optionally used to mark the topic of a question. Gives a sense of courtesy.
Karlusri maypim kachkan?And where is Carlos?
Maypitaq tiyankiri?And where do you live?
(transitive) to see, to notice, to observe
(intransitive) to speak, to talk, to express
(intransitive) to go, to walk, to travel

Testimonial past. Past tense of personally known facts. Compare to -sqa.
Maryapa p'unchawninpi tusukurqani.
I danced on Marya’s birthday.

Completed action; movement outwards.
riy (“to go”) → rirquy (“to go out, leave”)
chayay (“to arrive”) → chayarquy (“to finally arrive”)
a kind of cactus, Opuntia floccosa
(transitive) to do, make, work, create, apply

Evidential suffix, second-hand information. Indicates that the speaker has not directly experienced the information at hand; hearsay
Qusqumantas kanki. ― (They say that) you are from Cusco.
Inisqa qayna ñañantas watukusqan. ― Inez visited her sister yesterday (so I heard).

Evidential suffix, second-hand information. Indicates that the speaker has not directly experienced the information at hand; hearsay
Chay llaqta sumaqsi.(I hear that) that town is pretty.
Parachkansi.(I heard that) it is raining.
Anchapsi waqachinki wamrayta.(They say that) you make my child cry excessively.

mikhuspa rimayto talk while eating

large needle for sewing or fastening

Iterative. Indicates a recurring or repeated action.
phaway (“to fly”) → phawaykachay (“to flutter”)

Indicates second-person singular possessive.
mikhuna (“food”) → mikhunayki (“your food”)

Indicates second-person plural possessive.
mikhuna (“food”) → mikhunaykichik (“your (pl) food”)

Indicates first-person exclusive plural possessive.
wasi (“house”) → wasiyku (“our (excl) house”)

Assistive. Indicates that an action helps to complete another action.
puriy (“to walk”) → puriysiy (“to help walk”)

Comitative. with, possessing, having ownership
Ñuqa karruyuqmi kani.

chunka kimsayuq
thirteen (lit. ten with three)

Change or discontinuity.  Like English already.
mana (“no”) → manaña "no longer"
Riqsiniña.
"I already know."

already, now
Ña riqsini.
"I already know."
